channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: California Fires Keep Growing, With No End in Sight
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom pledged that the state was “putting everything we have” on the ravaging wildfires, acknowledging that even that was not enough to blunt their spread.
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: Lori Loughlin Gets 2 Months in College Admissions Case
item.description: The scandal has forced change to admissions rules, yet some observers say the shifts weren’t sweeping enough.
item.dc:creator: Kate Taylor
item.media:description: Lori Loughlin and her husband, Mossimo Giannulli, last year.

item.title: Postal Crisis Hits Rural America Hard
item.description: The Postal Service is crucial to farmers and rural areas that President Trump won in 2016. Now, residents worry it is being dismantled.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rhiannon Hampson, right, fed chickens on her farm in Thomaston, Maine, on Thursday. Farmers and other rural residents say they are particularly vulnerable to the crisis roiling the postal system.

item.title: As Wildfires Rage, Californians Fear the Coronavirus at Shelters
item.description: Evacuees along the rural Central Coast have fled wildfires, but more populated areas bring more risk from the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Cenaida Perez and her 3-year-old daughter, Adriana, at an evacuation center in Vacaville, Calif. They were forced out of their home because of a mandatory wildfire evacuation.

item.title: A Glimmer of Hope for Trump? How Bush Mounted a Comeback in 1988
item.description: For Biden, a cautionary tale. For Trump, a search for his own Willie Horton.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:description: George H.W. Bush won the presidency in 1988 by a margin of 53 percent to 46 percent.

item.title: Why Some Tropical Fish Are Gettin’ Squiggly With It
item.description: On occasion, different species of anglerfish produce hybrid offspring even more colorful than the parents.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Various species of angelfish and their putative hybridized offspring. Row A, from left, a Griffis and a goldspotted angelfish; Row B, a red stripe and a lemonpeel angelfish; Row C, a flame and a rusty angelfish; Row D, a swallowtail and a bellus angelfish.

item.title: Joe Biden and the 'Convention Bounce'
item.description: After the Democratic primary campaign came to an abrupt halt in late March as the coronavirus swept through the nation, the Democrats and Republicans have looked to the conventions as their candidates’ biggest stage.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. accepts the Democratic nomination for President at the Chase Center in Wilmington, Del. on Thursday.

item.title: Cartilage Is Grown in the Arthritic Joints of Mice
item.description: Researchers discovered a way to awaken dormant stem cells and transform them into cartilage. If the technique works in humans, it may help ease debilitating joint pain.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: An x-ray of a healthy mouse. In an experiment, mice with arthritis so bad they had trouble walking showed improvement after receiving stimulation of the stem cells in their knees.

item.title: Trump’s Approval Rating, Biden’s Speech: 2020 Campaign Highlights
item.description: The Democratic National Convention, on the whole, was aimed more at appealing to moderates than rallying the base. Will the Republicans take the opposite approach?
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
item.media:description: Residents of The Villages, Fla., held a golf cart parade on Friday to celebrate the Democratic ticket.

item.title: Covid in the Classroom? Shhh. Some Schools Are Keeping It Quiet
item.description: Some states and school districts provide detailed data on school outbreaks. Others choose to keep such information under wraps.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Charlotte Kesl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buses at Camden County High School in Kingsland, Ga. Some parents and teachers in the district are concerned that it isn’t reporting confirmed coronavirus cases.

item.title: Justice Dept. Questions Former C.I.A. Director for 8 Hours
item.description: John O. Brennan is a witness, not a target, in the inquiry being led by John H. Durham, a U.S. attorney, but the C.I.A. under Barack Obama could be subject to further criticism by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: John O. Brennan oversaw the C.I.A.’s inquiry into — and effort to stop — Russia’s campaign to intervene in the 2016 election.

item.title: Military Surveillance Planes Didn’t Spy on Protesters, Pentagon Report Finds
item.description: But the Air Force’s inspector general concluded that National Guard officials failed to obtain prior approval from Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper to use the planes.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The report concluded that Mark T. Esper, the defense secretary, should have had the final word over such delicate missions to prevent the military from using its vast arsenal for law enforcement purposes without proper oversight.

item.title: Trump Holds a Rare White House Funeral for His Younger Brother, Robert
item.description: It was the first time a president has held an East Room funeral for a member of his family in nearly 100 years.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The hymn “Abide With Me” was played on bagpipes after the funeral for Robert S. Trump that President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, hosted on Friday at the White House.

item.title: Biden Always Had a Simple Message. He Rode It to the Nomination.
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. never wavered from his central message: that President Trump was a danger to American democracy, while he was a stable, experienced leader. Now it will be tested in a fierce battle with the president.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden accepts the Democratic nomination for President at the Chase Center in Wilmington, Del., on Thursday.

item.title: A Presidential Historian Makes a Rare Appearance in Today’s Political Arena
item.description: Jon Meacham’s remarks at this week’s Democratic National Convention sprang from a long friendship with Joe Biden and a desire to add historical context to the present moment.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.category: The Soul of America: The Battle for Our Better Angels (Book)
item.media:credit: Democratic National Convention, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author Jon Meacham spoke Thursday during the Democratic National Convention. “The request was, define the soul of America, and do it quick,” he said.

item.title: Ex-Green Beret Charged With Spying for Russia in Elaborate Scheme
item.description: Prosecutors said he provided classified information to Russian intelligence operatives for years, betraying the United States.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.media:description: The suspect, who once held top security clearances, was scheduled to appear in federal court in Alexandria, Va., on Monday. It was unclear whether he had a lawyer.

item.title: National Zoo Panda Gives Birth
item.description: Mei Xiang, a 22-year-old giant panda at the Smithsonian zoo in Washington, D.C., is the oldest panda to give birth in the United States, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Marie Fazio
item.media:description: Mei Xiang, a giant panda, has three surviving cubs that now live in China.

item.title: Why Antibody Tests Won’t Help You Much
item.description: Most antibody tests are useful only for large population surveys, diagnosis in certain children or when initial diagnostic testing fails, according to an expert panel.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A rapid coronavirus antibody test showing a negative result in San Dimas, Calif., last month.

item.title: Hundreds of Trees Burned at Big Basin Redwoods State Park
item.description: Some of the ancient, towering conifers in Big Basin Redwoods State Park are a casualty of the fires that have wracked the state.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler and Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Randy Vazquez/The Mercury News via Getty Images
item.media:description: A redwood tree burning near the headquarters of Big Basin Redwoods State Park in Boulder Creek, Calif., on Thursday.

item.title: Climate Activists Gain Seats on Harvard Oversight Board
item.description: The candidates were the first ones elected through a petition campaign since 1989, when anti-apartheid activists put Archbishop Desmond Tutu on the panel.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harvard, with an endowment of more than $40 billion, has resisted calls to drop fossil fuel investments from its portfolio.

item.title: The Dreaded Lanternbug, Scourge of Agriculture, Spreads in New Jersey
item.description: The insect poses a serious threat to American crops, particularly vineyards, and inspires creative backyard methods of eliminating them.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: The spotted lanternfly feeds on sap from fruit trees and grape vines, which some economists estimate could cost the state of Pennsylvania at least $324 million annually.

item.title: Nina Popova, Dancer Who Fled Bolsheviks and Nazis, Dies at 97
item.description: Ms. Popova, who grew up in Russia, toured the globe, danced on Broadway and became a teacher. She died of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Europe is entering a new phase in the pandemic as a fresh wave of infection strikes countries that had initially reined in the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: New Safety Standards for Moviegoing as U.S. Theaters Reopen
item.description: The nation’s major multiplex chains are selling tickets again, and they have announced uniform health protocols to make patrons feel safer.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: Socially distanced guests at AMC in Las Vegas on Thursday. The nation’s largest theater chains hope to convince Americans that moviegoing is safe.

item.title: What to Know About Stuttering
item.description: The speech disorder can play havoc with sociability, relationships, even identity, but there are ways to handle it.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Brayden Harrington, a 13-year-old New Hampshire resident who spoke at the Democratic National Convention on Thursday, each have stutters.

item.title: Fact-Checking the Democratic National Convention
item.description: The four-day virtual event focused on character rather than policy. Still, Democrats exaggerated about Social Security, jobs and the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. attacked President Trump on Social Security funding using an exaggerated claim.

item.title: Golden State Killer Sentenced to Life in Prison Without Parole
item.description: Prosecutors said that Joseph James DeAngelo committed 13 murders and nearly 50 rapes that terrorized California in the 1970s and ’80s.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Joseph James DeAngelo apologized at his sentencing hearing to his victims and the families of the victims he killed more than four decades ago.

item.title: Deidre Davis Butler, Who Fought for Disability Rights, Dies at 64
item.description: A wheelchair user herself, she helped draft a landmark law and held government posts championing people with disabilities, especially those of color.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: The 7 Takeaways From The 2020 DNC
item.description: Joe Biden rallied the party around him, with help from Barack Obama and Bernie Sanders. But even as Democrats reach out to disaffected moderates, they’re also holding together a fractured coalition.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. joined Senator Kamala Harris after she accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Leonora O’Reilly, Suffragist Who Fought for Working Women
item.description: She was a charismatic and powerful public speaker who pushed for equal pay for equal work, better labor standards and overall empowerment for women.
item.dc:creator: Susan Ware

item.title: DeJoy Tells Senators Election Mail Will Be Delivered ‘Fully and on Time’
item.description: The postmaster general, under fire for recent changes that have slowed mail delivery, defended his approach and asked Congress to help free the Postal Service from costly retirement obligations.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Emily Cochrane

item.title: Economic Data Points to Pause in Recovery as Aid Programs Expire
item.description: The economy’s rebound showed signs of stagnating. Then enhanced unemployment benefits and a small-business loan program expired.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Consumer spending, which makes up 70 percent of the economy, began flatlining last month.

item.title: Trump says he is ‘the only thing standing between the American dream and total anarchy.’
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: In his remarks, President Trump painted a picture of death, destruction and economic ruin if voters choose Democrats in November.

item.title: Margaret and Jimmy Shaw, Married for 62 Years, Die Apart at 79 and 80
item.description: The couple, who eloped at 17, came from humble roots and were mainstays in their Miami church. They died of the coronavirus in separate hospital rooms.
item.dc:creator: John Leland

item.title: School Nurses, in Short Supply and on the Front Lines
item.description: Finland, Israel, South Korea, Kenya, and the UK are all preparing for the school year differently.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:description: Children kept their distance as they arrived at school in Helsinki, Finland, in May.

item.title: Who spoke the most at the D.N.C. and what it tells us about the party.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens

item.title: Tropical Storms Laura and Marco Form
item.description: Tropical Storm Laura formed in the Atlantic, while Marco, a second potential hurricane, moved toward the Gulf of Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: A satellite image of the two storms on Friday morning.

item.title: States file a joint lawsuit over changes to post office operations.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Hailey Fuchs
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested outside the Greensboro, N.C., home of Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, last week.

item.title: California Wildfires Explained: Why Does The State Have So Many?
item.description: There are four key ingredients to the disastrous wildfire seasons in the West, and climate change figures prominently.
item.dc:creator: Kendra Pierre-Louis and John Schwartz
item.media:description: A wildfire approached Interstate 80 near Vacaville, Calif., on Wednesday.

item.title: A Rip in the Fabric of Interstellar Dreams
item.description: The iconic Arecibo radio telescope is temporarily crippled by an accident.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: The gash viewed from below. The dome that hangs over the reflector dish and the platform to access the dome were also damaged.

item.title: Facebook Braces Itself for Trump to Cast Election Results Doubts
item.description: The world’s biggest social network is working out what steps to take should President Trump use its platform to dispute the vote.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Trump at a campaign rally in Yuma, Ariz. He has questioned the legitimacy of the vote-by-mail system.

item.title: Four moments that defined the final night of the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. pitched himself as a sober, seasoned leader who stood the best chance of defeating President Trump.

item.title: To Pay Rent and Avoid Eviction, Tenants Cash In Their Dreams
item.description: Federal aid and eviction bans have kept many tenants in their homes. With that support ebbing, it can take charity and sacrifice to avoid dislocation.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty and Gillian Friedman
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: After losing her two jobs and then her unemployment pay, Nura Moshtael felt she had no choice but to pack up her apartment and move in with her mother in her childhood home.

item.title: Join us now (live!) for a recap of the Democratic convention.
Are N95 Masks Helpful for Wildfire Smoke?
item.description: Friday: People with respiratory illnesses may be more vulnerable right now. Also: Are N95 masks recommended for wildfires?
item.dc:creator: Marie Tae McDermott
item.media:description: The San Francisco skyline is obscured by smoke from wildfires. Covid-19 and smoke is a dangerous combination, as both affect the respiratory system, making those exposed to the virus more vulnerable.

item.title: Brayden Harrington, a boy with a stutter, gave a gripping convention speech.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman and Glenn Thrush

item.title: Breaking Down the Biggest Moments of Biden’s Speech
item.description: Katie Glueck, a politics reporter, has covered Joe Biden for over 15 months. Here are her takeaways from his nomination acceptance speech.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kerr, Natalie Reneau and Yousur Al-Hlou
item.media:description: Aides to Joseph R. Biden Jr. hope to capitalize on all the focus on President Trump during the Republican National Convention next week by sharpening their criticism.

item.title: How Steve Bannon’s arrest disrupted his attempts to stay relevant.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt and Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Bannon leaving Federal District Court in Manhattan on Thursday. He was arrested on charges of defrauding donors to a campaign to privately fund a border wall.
